From freezing cold Austin, Texas. CHUCK: Do you want to introduce yourself really quickly? REN√â: Sure, I‚Äôd love to. I‚Äôm an iOS Architect here in Austin Texas at a company called Mutual Mobile. Ever since the iPhone came out, I‚Äôve been really interested in iOS, learning Objective-C and getting my hands dirty with all the versions of iOS that Apple likes to release over and over and over again. I‚Äôm just passionate about technology. CHUCK: Cool. So the topic for today is, ‚ÄúIs Swift Ready For Primetime?‚Äù REN√â: The short answer to that question is I think ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù but there‚Äôs obviously a lot more to that than a yes or no answer. JAIM: Okay, we‚Äôre done here. Great show! Alright! CHUCK: That was what I was going to say. You said ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù We‚Äôre done! Yay! [Chuckling] But not quite, huh? What is the nuance then to the conversation? REN√â: The thing is, I‚Äôve built a couple of apps in Swift already and it‚Äôs doable. You can build a full iOS app and ship it to the App Store written completely in Swift. The questions are more about, ‚ÄúDo you have the time to go through the learning curve?‚Äù and ‚ÄúDo you have the time to struggle with Xcode and some of the pieces that aren‚Äôt quite baked yet?‚Äù There are a lot of pieces with the compiler and the IDE that aren‚Äôt quite finished yet, and so you have to really think about, ‚ÄúDo I have the time to spend on this?‚Äù CHUCK: So is it really a question of tooling then? REN√â: Yeah, it‚Äôs really a tooling thing because the language is there; it interops really well with Objective-C; you‚Äôre able to use all the same patterns that you use normally. It‚Äôs a little weird though, when you‚Äôre doing things like target-action and stuff like that. But yeah, it‚Äôs a tooling thing. The tools get you there, but when you‚Äôre doing Objective-C, there are all these nice things that Xcode does for you automatically that aren‚Äôt quite there yet. One of my biggest pet peeves honestly is just line formatting. Every time I indent a line over, in Swift it just doesn‚Äôt do anything. It just basically indents you all the way to the left-hand side; it‚Äôs really annoying. PETE: Is that supposed to be the standard Swift way of doing line formatting, or is it just the Xcode that crappy? REN√â: I just think they haven‚Äôt built that in yet. That goes line in line with the fact that Xcode refactoring, it doesn‚Äôt support Swift yet. You can‚Äôt do refactoring with Swift, so all the refactoring tools like renaming classes and stuff that you don‚Äôt really think about that you just do day-to-day, when you find that those tools aren‚Äôt there, you‚Äôll appreciate them a lot more, I guess. PETE: I would argue that Xcode doesn‚Äôt really support refactoring in Objective-C yet [chuckles]. REN√â: That is true, that is true. PETE: That‚Äôs cool. I think you might be the first person I‚Äôve spoken to that actually uses the Rename Class and stuff like that. REN√â: It‚Äôs pretty handy for quick changes and stuff like that. JAIM: Well it finally works. It took a long time before it would detect changes in the storyboard [crosstalk 04:49]. PETE: Oh I just gave up on it a long time ago. Maybe I should revisit the refactoring and see if it works now. ANDREW: It‚Äôs still not great, but ‚Äì. ALONDO: Yeah, I was going to say it‚Äôs better, but I still [crosstalk 04:58]. ANDREW: But it works enough to be useful. REN√â: It‚Äôs not as good as AppCode, for sure. It‚Äôs not there yet. ANDREW: Ren√©, something I wanted to ask. Some friends and I were discussing Swift and especially the state of the tools a couple of days ago, and I haven‚Äôt done a lot of Swift ‚Äì I haven‚Äôt done any serious Swift programming for a real app yet. But one complaint somebody brought up was that the debugger does some kind of interesting things when you‚Äôre trying to debug Swift and he‚Äôs had quite a bit of trouble with that. Have you seen that? Does the debugger seem like it works pretty well for Swift? REN√â: Well, yeah. There are a lot of interesting things when you‚Äôre using the debugger. The main thing is when you‚Äôre debugging something in Swift, the LLDB prompt is in Swift itself. And so whenever you‚Äôre debugging things that are in Objective-C, which is basically most of your code because all the Apple frameworks are still written in Objective-C, while you‚Äôre debugging through that, the bridge isn‚Äôt quite clean. There‚Äôs actually something you can do ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know the command off the top of my head, but there‚Äôs a way that you can tell LLDB to switch over to Objective-C. It‚Äôs a matter of just ‚Äì it‚Äôs a nuance, and thinking, ‚ÄúOkay, am I in Objective-C or am I in Swift? Do we ‚Äì changing the debugger to have a prettier output?‚Äù It‚Äôs an output thing; it‚Äôs not very pretty. You also get really weird things when you have protocol variables and constants because of the way that the compiler optimizes virtualization [inaudible 06:15], virtualization and stuff ‚Äì it gets really icky. It‚Äôs not very clear. But again, there are commands to get you through that, but again, it‚Äôs not super straightforward. What I recommend is watching the WWDC session on Debugging with Swift. I watch that over and over again; I learn something new every time. ANDREW: Cool! I didn‚Äôt know about that ability to switch over to Objective-C mode. Let‚Äôs see if we can look that up and put it in the show notes. REN√â: Yeah, that's super helpful. Super, super helpful. ANDREW: Going in a little different direction, speaking of this whole debate about whether Swift‚Äôs ready for primetime, I think one of the important things to consider is what are the advantages of using Swift right now. It‚Äôs pretty easy to come up with some disadvantages, like the learning curve and the tools are a little half-baked, but I think the discussion‚Äôs more interesting when you know what the advantages are. So I‚Äôm curious to know what advantages you think you‚Äôre getting out of using Swift right now? We know the theoretical advantages, but what are you seeing really useful? REN√â: I‚Äôve been doing pure Swift for the last four months now, to the point where my Objective-C is getting a little rusty, which is scary. But the benefits that I see is once you do a learning curve and once you know how to work your way around some weird Xcode things, honestly, it sped up my development time two-fold. I can write apps twice as fast as I could before. It‚Äôs not one big thing that I could pinpoint that‚Äôs, say, ‚ÄúThis is why.‚Äù It‚Äôs more of a lot of little things ‚Äì a lot of little things that in Objective-C you have to take care of, like having hetero files and your imports and a lot of fun stuff. All these little things that you don‚Äôt have to do in Swift kind of add up and really help speed up your development process. That‚Äôs what I would say is the number one benefit. ANDREW: I think people have talked about classes of bugs that Swift should make much harder to introduce accidentally. Have you seen that kind of a benefit? I mean, there are things like in Objective-C you can message nil and it just silently fails, and Swift doesn‚Äôt let you do that or at least it‚Äôs kind of the whole optional thing. But have you done enough to notice whether your code seems less buggy by default? REN√â: I haven‚Äôt really noticed it, but I know that it does protect for a lot of really lower-level kind of bugs like buffer overruns and stuff like typecasting and stuff that Swift just won‚Äôt let you do. If anything, I‚Äôll say that one thing I really like about Swift is that the best practice that Apple advocates for for Objective-C are basically encoded into the compiler to the point where your code won‚Äôt compile if you don‚Äôt follow the best practices. They‚Äôve done that in lots of different places. For example, with the initializer, there are a lot of rules as to how initializers work, and that‚Äôs just following the best practices that were always there in Objective-C, but that you could always not follow. PETE: Have you noticed it‚Äôs changed ‚Äì using Swift [inaudible 08:55] Objective-C has changed the style of programming? I guess I‚Äôm getting towards the whole functional aspect [inaudible 09:03]. I feel like idiomatic Swift is going to look different from idiomatic Objective-C. REN√â: Yup, it does feel very different, and it really depends whether you‚Äôre interfacing with existing Cocoa Touch frameworks or if you‚Äôre doing something off to the side that‚Äôs pure Swift. Those two things feel very different, because as soon as you start touching frameworks, you‚Äôre kind of having to opt-in to the Objective-C interop, and you‚Äôre having to do some weird things to make your Swift look a little bit more like Objective-C versus when you‚Äôre in a pure Swift file and class, you basically can do whatever you want. And that does feel very different. PETE: Do you find yourself trying to push set up adapters or stuff that bridges between as well so you don‚Äôt have to deal with the Objective-C stuff as much? REN√â: Not so much, and mainly because I‚Äôve been doing pure Swift. I‚Äôve talked to other people that have done a mixed language project, and those guys are definitely doing a lot of adapters because they have situations where some legacy Objective-C code is now calling into their Swift code. When you‚Äôre doing that, there are always Swift language features that Objective-C just doesn‚Äôt even know about, like tuples and things like that, and so you feel like a method returning a tuple, you can‚Äôt call that from Objective-C. I know a lot of people are putting a bridge between the two languages to translate returning a tuple means, ‚ÄúOkay, return this object‚Äù or something like that. PETE: Gotcha. I guess that would factor into the decision of when is the ‚ÄúSwift ready for primetime‚Äù thing, in the context of someone‚Äôs project. If they‚Äôve got this huge, existing application, they‚Äôre going to be paying quite a lot of tax initially, I suppose, to set up all of that stuff before they start seeing the productivity benefits of using Swift [inaudible 10:52]. JAIM: You brought up one example about a tuple, or something that wouldn‚Äôt exist in Objective-C. So if you‚Äôve got your Swift world code and your Objective-C world code, if interop‚Äôs a priority, your interfaces ‚Äì you just want a design that they‚Äôre returning things that Objective-C would understand. REN√â: Right, right. Honestly, the best way to do it is to not return something like the tuple. That‚Äôs the easiest way, because that way you can directly annotate your stuff as add Objective-C, making it visible to Objective-C. But if you really, really want to do all the cool fantasy Swift stuff, then yeah, you can do a bridge. But there‚Äôs a lot of work that you have to do, right? If you‚Äôre returning a tuple, then I have to turn that into an Objective-C object or struct or something so that I can pass it back to my Objective-C interface. PETE: I guess along the same lines, one of the things that I‚Äôm ‚Äì this is really interesting to me to talk to someone who‚Äôs been in the trenches using this stuff. The impedance mismatch that seems like is going to be the biggest thing with using Objective-C APIs from Swift is the whole optional thing, right? REN√â: Yup. PETE: All of those Objective-C APIs are designed around the idea of things being nil and obviously, that‚Äôs not the case for Swift. My assumption has been ‚Äì and this is all theoretical, so I want to find out how far off I am ‚Äì that it‚Äôs going to be super painful messing around with all of that wrapping stuff up in optionals and unwrapping it in optionals at that boundary where you‚Äôre talking to an Objective-C API. But once you‚Äôve done that wrapping and unwrapping, everything behind that that‚Äôs in pure Swift should flow a lot better than in the old Objective-C world. Is that roughly how it feels, or do you find yourself still having to mess around a bunch with boxing and unboxing things even when you‚Äôre not using a legacy API? REN√â: Back when I was learning Swift, I was doing a lot of boxing and unboxing, and the more comfortable I get with Swift, the less I‚Äôve been doing optionals when I don‚Äôt need to. The impedance mismatch ‚Äì one of the nice things is it does get cleaner once you come over to Swift, but even better. Everything in Objective-C gets brought over as what‚Äôs called an implicitly unwrapped optional, which, if you audit your Objective-C code, it can guarantee that you‚Äôre actually passing a real instance back. Because it‚Äôs implicitly unwrapped, you don‚Äôt need to unbox it to use it. That‚Äôs a very dangerous thing though, because if, for some reason, that Objective-C method does return nil for some case and you‚Äôre using the implicitly unwrapped optional straight out without unboxing it, you‚Äôre going to crash at runtime. But this is what Apple has done. They‚Äôve gone through all the methods in Cocoa Touch and audited them and said, ‚ÄúOkay, can I guarantee whether or not this returns a value?‚Äù And that‚Äôs why when Swift first came out, everything from Cocoa Touch was an exclamation mark ‚Äì it was implicitly unwrapped. Now, you‚Äôre starting to see that most of the methods are either optionals with a question mark, meaning it could return nil, or just flat out a value ‚Äì a non-optional. Unfortunately, Apple hasn‚Äôt given us the ability to audit our methods and mark them as guaranteeing returning value or not, but because they‚Äôre implicitly unwrapped, we still have the ability to not have to unbox every single time. PETE: I guess I kind of assumed that that would be part of the work of putting adapters or bridges or whatever in place, is putting something around our old Objective-C code that just says, ‚ÄúThis stuff is explicitly going to return an optional thing. This thing is definitely going to return a value.‚Äù It would be great if we could do that without having to write code to do it. Presumably that‚Äôs an option; it‚Äôs just write a little Swift adapter doodad that makes it explicit whether the thing‚Äôs going to [crosstalk 14:30] REN√â: Yup, you could do that. For sure. I mean, it‚Äôs interesting because here at work, we‚Äôre doing what we call i-Swift, which is basically training for all of our iOS engineers, trying to teach everybody Swift. It‚Äôs really interesting, seeing the progression of learning across from Objective-C to Swift guys. One of the things that‚Äôs very difficult is ‚Äì optionals is not something that just comes to mind very quickly. It‚Äôs something that I definitely know that it took me a long time to really grasp how you use them. The concept is not hard to grasp, but the actual usage of it gets kind of difficult. The whole implicitly unwrapped optional has been an interesting topic because a lot of people ask me, ‚ÄúWhat is this whole question mark exclamation point thing? I just usually switch one from the other until it compiles and I‚Äôm ready to go4 [chuckling].‚Äù I kind of freak out a little bit and say, ‚ÄúNo, no! Don‚Äôt do that.‚Äù It‚Äôs a learning curve; I guess that's the bottom line. PETE: Yeah. I remember Scala has a lot of these same functional-y things and lots of monadic things like optionals. Definitely for me, it was this really big ‚Äì it was a learning curve, but it was a learning curve with a couple of steps. That was just the initial conceptual thing, which, like you say, it‚Äôs actually pretty straightforward, and then there‚Äôs learning to use it. But I got a second or third kind of leveling up when I started to realize that it‚Äôs not just about nullability for things; it‚Äôs like you can use the same patterns that you used for optionals. You can think of lots of things of having that same property and you start seeing a monadic thing of ‚Äì. Basically you start seeing lots of conditionals just disappear from your code and you just start treating things as data streaming tree functions rather than this imperative ‚Äúdo this if that‚Äôs true; otherwise, do this other thing.‚Äù I don‚Äôt know. I suspect that lots of people are going to have several epiphany ‚ÄúAha!‚Äù moments as they really start grokking all of this stuff in Swift. It‚Äôs not just that initial learning thing; it‚Äôs like this extra leveling up moments which are super cool and suddenly the scales fall from your eyes and you suddenly see that everything‚Äôs turned into a monad. REN√â: For me, the ‚ÄúAha!‚Äù moment really was when I realized that optionals isn‚Äôt the feature for Swift. To me, the feature is nonoptionals ‚Äì the fact that you can have something that‚Äôs guaranteed to have a value. That‚Äôs really what I find is really interesting because it gives me a level of comfort when I‚Äôm programming and coding and knowing I‚Äôm going to have a value here and not having to worry about the weird things that can happen in Objective-C. PETE: Yeah, I think of it a little bit the same way as going from a language where you had to do error checking on every function to a language where you have exception handling. You suddenly realize that if you deal with your exceptional cases at the boundaries of your code like where things could be failing or not failing, then all of your code inside starts to become a lot cleaner because you no longer have to start worrying all the time. You have to stop being so defensive and being, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know ‚Äì maybe it could be nil, maybe it couldn‚Äôt be nil. I‚Äôve got to check again and again and again.‚Äù I get that same feeling of ‚Äì it really frees you up to start focusing on the problem rather than thinking about all the boring plumbing of programming. REN√â: Right. That reminds me of another thing that I really love about Swift is all the stuff I don‚Äôt have to do. In terms of readability, it‚Äôs just a lot easier to read. I find it way easier to read than Objective-C, just because there‚Äôs a lot of, like you said, a lot of things that you don‚Äôt even have to do. A lot of code just goes away and the language takes care of a lot of things for you. CHUCK: Can you give us some examples of that? I know you talked a little bit about it earlier, but what areas in particular do you not have to do anything about? REN√â: For starters, you going to need to have a header, which is great, so you don‚Äôt have to ‚Äì every time you create a class ‚Äì worry about two files, and if I change the interface here, you have to change the interface there. That whole thing just goes away. Let me think for a second ‚Äì what else melts away? I mean, the error-checking when you have nonoptionals, when you‚Äôre stopping to having to check all that stuff with pattern-matching and switch statements ‚Äì super powerful. The fact that I can switch on an expression is incredibly useful. It just makes a lot of things more straightforward. One of my favorite ones is you can initialize a property at the declaration site in Swift, which you can‚Äôt do in Objective-C, and that has cleaned up a lot of things for me. The [inaudible 18:51] stuff just straight up in the declaration at the top and there‚Äôs just a lot of things that you couldn‚Äôt do in Objective-C that you wanted to do that now you can do, and that is a great feeling to be able to have more control over what you want to do. ALONDO: So what if I took the flipped approach and asked the question coming from the other side as someone who hasn‚Äôt really taken a deep dive into Swift ‚Äì what am I giving up in this transition? REN√â: Well, right now you‚Äôre not giving up much because there‚Äôs so much interop between Swift and Objective-C and you can always go back into Objective-C when you need things that you could do before. But what you‚Äôre losing in a pure, pure Swift environment is the dynamic language. Swift is completely type safe, so there are a lot of things that you can do in Objective-C that you can‚Äôt do in Swift. For example, swizzle methods. I can‚Äôt do any swizzling in Swift because the compiler tends to optimize method calls in lining the function pointers and so you‚Äôre losing the whole, rich Objective-C runtime that you can do a lot of interesting things. For example, when you‚Äôre parsing JSON, you can have some introspection on your model objects and say ‚ÄúOkay, let me match up my property names with this JSON key names and then let me prepopulate ‚Äì.‚Äù You can‚Äôt do that. I tried doing that in Swift; there‚Äôs no way because it‚Äôs all type safe. And so you lose a lot of the dynamic nature of Objective-C. ANDREW: That brings up something I wanted to ask about, which is, we know we can always still write stuff in Objective-C if we want to. At least right now, because of the good interoperability. I wonder if there are cases where you found that it still actually just makes sense to write something in Objective-C. The thing I‚Äôm kind of thinking about is the really low-level C-API, so things like Core Audio or IOKit, a POSIX Socket programming or something like that. From what little I‚Äôve seen it seems like Swift make some of that stuff possibly more difficult that it was in Objective-C/C. Have you run into that at all? REN√â: I have run into that a little bit. There are two sides to that coin when talking to C from Swift. One of the pros is that a lot of the memory management gets done automatically for you. Apple has also audited those methods and put some identifiers or annotations that tell whether it‚Äôs +1 or not, and so you basically get ARC for C calls. That removes all the [inaudible 21:09] release stuff that you had to do if you were going down to Core Graphics or any of the C frameworks. That‚Äôs the positive side. The negative side is, yeah, it gets really arcane when you have C-API that‚Äôs using things like function pointers. For example, one time I was trying to do NSRunLoop and set up a RunLoop observer with a C function call back. Back when I was doing it, there was no way to do it. I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs the case anymore; I would be surprised if it has changed, but I wasn‚Äôt able to do that. That was the one time that I was actually unable to do something because I was in Swift, just flat out because the language didn‚Äôt support it. But that‚Äôs the only thing. For the most part, it‚Äôs been pretty delightful to use C-APIs in Swift. ANDREW: That gets at what I was thinking of Core Audio, in particular. There are a lot of Core Audio functions that take a callback function and it‚Äôs just a C function pointer and I wondered if that was more difficult than Swift. Because it‚Äôs super easy in Objective-C, and you could even just quickly trampoline back into your real Objective-C code. REN√â: Yeah, it‚Äôs definitely arcane. They‚Äôve wrapped the concept of a pointer in their own types with NSMutablePointer and stuff like that, but it took me a little while to really grasp what was going on. If I was in Objective-C or C, I would have been able to do it right away. Again, it‚Äôs that tax that you pay that you don‚Äôt know upfront what you‚Äôre going to hit. I haven‚Äôt done millions of apps; I haven‚Äôt done super complicated apps, so I still don‚Äôt know what other taxes I may have to pay. It‚Äôs like ‚ÄúTake your own risk, at your own risk.‚Äù ANDREW: Well it seems to me that this is a case where the interoperability between Swift and Objective-C is probably actually a big advantage, not just for the fact that we need to interface with all these Objective-C Cocoa APIs. I‚Äôm not sure I think there‚Äôs anything wrong with writing small pieces of your app in Objective-C even going forward, and then calling those from Swift. REN√â: I agree with that, I agree with that. And actually, I want to go back to that question of ‚ÄúWhat makes sense to write in Objective-C?‚Äù Well, anything that‚Äôs dynamic. For example, that dynamic parser that does introspection on Objective-C model objects. I would still use Objective-C to build that because I don‚Äôt want to have to build a Swift code generator that parses JSON and the outputs a bunch of Swift files, and then you bundle inside your app and compile. I don‚Äôt like that. I‚Äôd rather just, at runtime, dynamically matchup my JSON keys with my model object property names. And so things like that, I would just do Objective-C, and I think there are a lot of other use cases out there that makes sense. Like you guys said, that‚Äôs where the interop is a huge advantage, that you have that option. CHUCK: I have a question regarding more of the ecosystem around Swift. We have all of the ecosystem that‚Äôs around Objective-C; is there good documentation? Are there good Stack Overflow questions, et cetera, et cetera around Swift yet, or we still waiting for the stuff to be written or asked or made? REN√â: I would say, at the very, very foundational level, there is great documentation from Apple. I mean, Apple has done a great job of updating the Swift Language Programming Guide, which is I think a huge feat because they‚Äôve changed the language so much since the very beginning and every time I go in there and I look at the revisions, it closely matches the diffs that I see in the developer portal. They‚Äôve done a really good job of keeping that up-to-date, and it‚Äôs actually a very well-written piece of documentation. The only problem with that though is it‚Äôs very detailed. It‚Äôs not like a good learning tool; it‚Äôs more like a reference where you want to learn a new topic and you can do a deep dive. It‚Äôs not a kind of book that you‚Äôd want to read from cover to cover. Higher level things like Stack Overflow ‚Äì I‚Äôve been finding a lot of things; I really have. I mean, there‚Äôs very few times where I type something into Google and I didn‚Äôt find anything, which is really nice. And also where there‚Äôs a lot of activity is the Apple Developer Forums. If you‚Äôve found some weird use cases where ‚Äì this is another caveat with Swift is ‚Äì if you‚Äôre doing any kind of enterprise distribution, for some weird reason, Apple changed the way that enterprise identity certs get created to the point where if you have it, if you include Swift in your app and you try to code sign ‚Äì. Or I guess when you try to open the app that was signed with the enterprise cert, the app just crashes. Unless you revoke your cert and create a new one, which is not what you want to do because then all your existing apps that are out there aren‚Äôt going to work anymore. It was a really arcane message. I put it into Google ‚Äì didn‚Äôt find anything. Went to the Apple Developer Forums, found four or five posts and got my answer really quickly. So I‚Äôve been finding a lot of answers out there, for sure. CHUCK: The other thing I‚Äôm wondering, have you released any apps written in Swift on the App Store? REN√â: I haven‚Äôt personally released anything. I released a bunch of stuff internally. My first Swift app was actually a Mac app for doing stuff with JIRA, for our engineers. You can do it for Mac apps too, I guess is the bottom line there, but no, I haven‚Äôt done anything in the App Store quite yet. CHUCK: The reason I‚Äôm asking is it seems like Apple tends to favor apps that use the new, cool thing that they‚Äôre trying to get people to use, and so I‚Äôm wondering if your app is written in Swift, are you more likely to get accepted or get promoted within the App Store because you‚Äôre using the technology that they want you to use? REN√â: I don‚Äôt know; that‚Äôs a very interesting question. Unlike all the other features, it‚Äôs not very user-facing. It‚Äôs not something that you can look at and know ‚ÄúOh, this is written in Swift‚Äù, right? It‚Äôs very invisible. Versus they want you to be using the accelerometer, they want you to use the camera, and every time they come up with new hardware, they really want you to ‚Äì. For example, the watch. All the apps that have WatchKit extensions, they‚Äôre going to get promoted and be at the very top of the App Store promotion list. But with Swift, I don‚Äôt know. I have no idea. I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if they weren‚Äôt just because they were so transparent. PETE: Yeah, I think it‚Äôs the same thing. I can‚Äôt imagine the average iPhone or iPad or whatever user being, ‚ÄúOh I want to get me a Swift-powered app.‚Äù Swift on the inside. I don‚Äôt think people care. ANDREW: Most people would have no idea what that even meant at all. CHUCK: Yeah. PETE: Right. REN√â: I think it just boils down to Swift is by nature a much safer language, so the chances of the app crashing on you is less. If we think back to 2008, when the iPhone first came out, the first apps that were coming out in the App Store, they would crash a lot. It was really easy to crash an app back then. With the introduction of ARC and now with Swift, Apple‚Äôs really trying to make it harder and harder for users to experience these poor experiences where the app‚Äôs just crashing and bail out on you. ANDREW: Yeah, and I think they‚Äôve done a good job. I think a big part of the problem for actually quite a long time was that you had all these people who were coming to iOS that were brand new and coming from platforms where some of those problems are already basically have been solved. I just remembered knowing that an app was obviously written by somebody and it was their first time because there were crashes due to memory management bugs and you could trigger them super easily. I‚Äôm really glad they‚Äôve removed that burden from people and you can be somebody who‚Äôs getting started and write an app that‚Äôs not going to have these dumb crashes that you wish you didn‚Äôt have to know anything about. REN√â: Yeah, that‚Äôs another big thing about Swift, just how Apple has put a focus on being able to learn the language with the whole Playground thing. I find a lot of Java engineers learning Swift fairly quickly; it‚Äôs very similar. There are a lot of similar concepts like generics and stuff, but just being able to pull up a Playground and just write code and see it execute immediately is just a huge advantage for learning the language, and I think it‚Äôs going to really help get new engineers on-board with the platform. It will be interesting to see a year or two from now how much the iOS community grows just because of Swift. CHUCK: So you think it lowers the learning curve in a significant way? REN√â: I think so, I really do. Just being able to execute code right away and not having to deal with Xcode build and run and all that fun stuff, it‚Äôs incredibly easy to teach someone how to program when they‚Äôre seeing every step of the execution running right as you‚Äôre typing the code. PETE: I wanted to go back a little bit to more of just the language itself. One of the things you mentioned a little bit early on is the difference between ‚Äì Objective-C is more of a dynamic, looser language while Swift has got an actual type block. That‚Äôs unfair to Objective-C to say Swift has actually got a type system. Objective-C kind of does. Have you seen yourself or other folks at Mutual Mobile who are learning this? Is that a big stumbling block, trying to figure out how to work with a type system that‚Äôs a little bit more restrictive, or does it tend to just get out of your way? REN√â: No, I definitely think it‚Äôs just because it‚Äôs so different. The type system in Swift is another thing that I really love about the language because it‚Äôs very uniform, but it‚Äôs very different in Objective-C. Objective-C engineers start learning Swift ‚Äì there are some simple things that maybe don‚Äôt come to mind immediately. For example, you don‚Äôt really think of instantiating an enumeration, right? You‚Äôre not really thinking in that term, but that‚Äôs how you do it. Everything in Swift is a first classes and type; everything gets instantiated; everything is basically an object. There are certain things that are stumbling blocks just because it‚Äôs so different. But the nice thing though is because it‚Äôs so uniform, once you get it, once you learn it, it applies to everything else. PETE: Yeah. Rick Hickey, the guy who created Clojure, has this really cool tool called Simple Made Easy or simple versus easy or something like that. He talks about how really powerful systems or really powerful languages are those that have a few small concepts that fit together really well and that you can use these few small concepts to model a bunch of different things. The type system is a good example of that, I would say, where once you‚Äôve learned it, you know how it works and it applies in lots of different ways. It applies for enumerations the same as it does for model objects in your code base versus Objective-C where there‚Äôs all these little, weird corner cases and special ways of doing things like ‚ÄúOh, there‚Äôs a macro system from C# days, there are also constants.‚Äù We have all these different ways of doing things, and so you have to learn all these different ways. I totally love this idea of a very simple language where maybe it‚Äôs a bit harder to learn the ideas upfront, but once you‚Äôve learned them, you know it and you can apply that same idea in lots of different concepts. REN√â: Yeah, that perfectly characterizes my experience with Swift so far. That describes it perfectly. PETE: It‚Äôs kind of ironic as well, because I think in that talk he‚Äôs like digging Scala, because Scala is just this ridiculous bag of 500 different language features versus Clojure which is just for [inaudible 32:07], basically. And so yeah, it‚Äôs kind of funny because I think the language I hear Swift‚Äôs compared most frequently to is Scala but I think it definitely doesn‚Äôt have the ridonculous amount of features that Scala does. JAIM: So what are the characterizations that I heard before, if you want to use Swift or Objective-C with a new project, what type of developer are you? Are you the type of person that physically gets CocoaPods and has ten going within an hour? Are you the person that uses the Apple way of doing things? If you‚Äôre doing the Apple way of doing things, I heard you had an easier time even this summer, but if you did a lot of CocoaPods, which might be Objective-C libraries, like AFNetworking or something like that, you had a harder time. What type of apps are you having success with? REN√â: What kind of apps in terms of tooling for engineers? JAIM: Tooling ‚Äì your approach. Are you doing a bunch of CocoaPods? Are you just sticking with the standard frameworks? REN√â: Well I am doing a lot of CocoaPods because I depend a lot on libraries that are written in Objective-C. At this point, since Swift is so new, all the Swift libraries, I just done trust them 100% yet. I don‚Äôt think that they‚Äôve matured yet and haven‚Äôt been adopted and put through their paces enough like the Objective-C libraries. So yeah, I use CocoaPods for everything, even my pure Swift apps. Again, that‚Äôs where the interop is super helpful because I can bring in all those existing libraries and still write all of my code in Swift, but when I need to call into stuff like networking, I can use AFNetworking to just find ‚Äì. What‚Äôs going to be interesting in the future when it comes to dependency management, for starters, Xcode does not support Swift in static libraries. CocoaPods is very dependent on static libraries. I mean, that‚Äôs what it does, right? It creates a bunch of static libraries that you link against. Right now, as it stands, I can‚Äôt write a Swift library and distribute with CocoaPods. Where Apple‚Äôs response to that would be will ‚Äì that‚Äôs why we enabled Cocoa Touch frameworks this year. For iOS 8 and above, you can actually do frameworks and bringing a new framework is so much easier. You don‚Äôt have to go through all those build settings and search heteropaths and all that fund stuff. The problem with frameworks is that because iOS 7 doesn‚Äôt know how to decrypt them, you can‚Äôt use them if you‚Äôre supporting 7 and below, so it‚Äôs 8 and above only. But it does support Swift, so that‚Äôs I think Apple‚Äôs preferred way of distributing Swift libraries ‚Äì it‚Äôs going to be through frameworks. ANDREW: I actually picked last week a project called Carthage that‚Äôs sort of a counterpart to CocoaPods by Justin Spahrsummers ‚Äì one of the guys at GitHub. Instead of building static libraries and putting them in your project, it actually just knows how to pull an open source project and build a dynamic framework. I kind of see that as the future ‚Äì well, I see it as a better approach than what CocoaPods does. And just a minor footnote is that frameworks have been supported on the Mac forever, so if you‚Äôre writing a Mac app, that framework approach is quite viable. PETE: That‚Äôs really exciting. I remember you picking that but I probably wasn‚Äôt paying attention. I didn‚Äôt realize how different the approach is. Having been someone who had to maintain a library that people will link into their apps, I‚Äôm very excited that the idea of having a real, grown up dependency management thing that doesn‚Äôt include messing around them, compiling everything yourself ‚Äì well compiling inside of your code, basically. That‚Äôs cool. We have him on and talk about that some more. ANDREW: Yeah, he would be great anyway. But yeah, that would be an interesting to talk about. I haven‚Äôt dug into actually using that yet. My goal right now is to get my open source projects working with it. It‚Äôs supposed to be pretty easy, but I haven‚Äôt even tried yet. CHUCK: So if I wanted to start a project in Swift, how would I get started? Do you just create a project the same way you normally would? How does the workflow change other than that you don‚Äôt have Dot.h and Dot.m files? REN√â: If you‚Äôre doing a pure Swift app, it‚Äôs actually very simple. When you create a new project in Xcode, it‚Äôll actually ask you what language you want it in ‚Äì Objective-C or Swift? It‚Äôs just a drop down and you select Swift and then you‚Äôre off and running. There are some things that won‚Äôt be there that you might be familiar with. There‚Äôs no main.m ‚Äì that‚Äôs gone ‚Äì and a lot of other things. That‚Äôs the main thing that‚Äôs gone. But other than that, you‚Äôre ready to go. As long as you create a new project, select Swift and you‚Äôll have all your baked in code like the viewControllers that come baked in with the templates. They‚Äôll all be in Swift and perfectly ready for you to use. ANDREW: Yeah, that brings up something else that I don‚Äôt think we touched on at all. Apple has also made it so that all the documentation for the existing frameworks, which are all written in Objective-C, and I think even the new frameworks, are mostly ‚Äì if not completely ‚Äì being written in Objective-C. Anyway, they‚Äôve made it so the documentation viewer will show you the Swift declaration for a method, as well as the Objective-C method. You can also view the headers for Objective-C stuff in the Objective-C headers that are part of the framework so you can view those in ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know what you call it. Swift mode, so you can see how ‚Äì you don‚Äôt have to do this mental translation yourself. The tools actually help you do that translation between the Objective-C APIs and the Swift APIs. REN√â: Which is great because a lot of things get brought in in a different way. Things like, you have an argument that‚Äôs type is id ‚Äì well that gets translated into any object. Block syntax to Clojure syntax. All these things that would be really hard for you to do in your head, it‚Äôs super helpful to be able to see the Swift version of those hetero files. ANDREW: I‚Äôve heard people say that if you want to, you can write an app in Swift that works exactly like the Objective-C app you would write, and I think what they mean is that you don‚Äôt have to use all of these new Swift-specific features. I think you kind of lose out on some of the benefits of Swift, but it doesn‚Äôt mean that there‚Äôs a much smaller learning curve than there would be. I mean, you‚Äôre still using the same frameworks and the same app architecture that we‚Äôre all used to as iOS developers. REN√â: I completely agree. In the course that I‚Äôm teaching here at Mutual Mobile, I didn‚Äôt introduce tuple; I didn‚Äôt introduce generics. We started basically the goal was, how can we get our engineers building an entire Swift app as quickly as possible? A way to do that was to just teach them what they needed to know ‚Äì things like optionals and interop and Clojures, but we didn‚Äôt have to talk about pattern-matching or we didn‚Äôt have to talk about enumeration, associated values. All these things that we didn‚Äôt really need to touch upon and they‚Äôre able to build an entire app. Now, is it as nice and as powerful as it could be if those apps were written with all the Swift features? Of course not. But we have a lot of time to learn the language and it‚Äôs just a matter of balancing out what you want to learn and the time that you have. One thing I wanted to touch on real quick was on Playgrounds, because I feel as I talk to engineers, it‚Äôs one of those things that you play around with it when you first get Xcode for the first time, and then you kind of forget about it. I use Playgrounds all the time, and I think the gotcha ‚Äì or I guess the ‚ÄúAha!‚Äù moment I had was when I was building a collection view layout. I thought, ‚ÄúMaybe I can just use Playgrounds so I can change the code and immediately see my layout and how it‚Äôs changing.‚Äù What I ended up doing was I put most of the code that I was writing inside of a framework so that I could then go into a Playground and start calling into it. It was one of those experiences that I was like, ‚ÄúWow, I really finally understood the power behind Playgrounds.‚Äù I was able to see my layout change before my eyes immediately without having to build and run, without having to put it on a simulator or put it on a device. I was able to see all the bugs that I had; I was able to change all the inputs immediately and kind of see how that affected my layout. It‚Äôs just a tool that I think not everyone thinks to use, but is super powerful. JAIM: Yeah, definitely. The faster you can shorten that feedback cycle, the faster you could learn and figure out what‚Äôs going on, so it‚Äôs definitely helpful. PETE: I‚Äôve got a quick question.
